Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: The Complexity of Global Change - Interactive Effects of Warming, Water Availability, CO2 and N on Grassland Ecosystem Function
Award.AbstractNarration:
Changes in temperature, precipitation, atmospheric CO2 concentration, and nitrogen deposition will likely continue to occur throughout the 21st century and will have significant impacts on forests, grasslands, and other vegetation across the planet. However, the effects of each of these factors alone may depend on changes in the other factors, and such interactions are poorly understood. Given this scientific gap, the objective of the proposed study is to increase understanding of the interactive effects of warming, precipitation, CO2, and nitrogen on long-term ecosystem responses. To meet this objective, experimental manipulations will be imposed in a unique open-air grassland experiment in Minnesota, to create all combinations of ambient and elevated temperature (ambient and +2Â°C), current and reduced growing season precipitation (ambient rainfall and 55% of ambient rainfall), ambient and elevated CO2 (current levels and those likely to occur late in the century), and ambient and enriched nitrogen supply (achieved with two levels of soil nitrogen supply). The study will determine the interactive effects of these four global change factors on performance of plants and soil organisms, and hence on plant production, soil fertility, and carbon acquisition and storage. Results of this project will also help in the development of models that predict how changes in vegetation will influence the global climate system through modifying the rise in atmospheric carbon dioxide levels and thus the rate of climate warming.

This project will educate a diverse group of undergraduates, including students from under-represented groups, and build ties to scientists from around the U.S. and the world. Results will be incorporated into outreach activities aimed at K-12 educators and aimed at training teachers in global change and sustainability curricula. Researchers will educate students and the public through classes, interviews with the press, participation in public forums, and advising government officials.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Over the life of the award we used a “climate change simulator” to expose open-air (chamberless) perennial grassland plots at Cedar Creek Ecosystem Science Reserve, Minnesota, USA to 16 different combinations of CO2, N, temperature and rainfall, that represent the range of conditions ecosystems might see in the future versus today. This is only one of a handful of such experiments in the world that realistically test ecosystem response to future conditions in a changing environment. We observed that plant biomass production and soil activity (measured as soil CO2 flux, largely from soil microbes) were overall most sensitive to CO2, followed by warming, nitrogen and rainfall, with biomass higher at elevated levels of each.  However, responses to each global change element were different depending on the levels of other global change drivers (that were manipulated in the study), indicating that the global scientific community needs to make understanding of such interactions a high priority. At present, without funding for such experiments, there is no direct way to learn more about such interactions, and all indirect ways, such as trying to statistically tease apart temporal or spatial patterns, are fraught with problems.

Results from these experimental plots were also components of many larger studies that included either a greater range of experimental plots at the Cedar Creek site, or at sites around the world. Several examples include:  1) these data were central to estimates of the economic value of plant diversity for soil carbon storage, 2) these data contributed to examinations of the stability and sensitivity of diversity effects under different climate and other global change regimes, 3) these data contributed to a synthesis of findings showing that mycorrhizae association is a primary control on the CO2 fertilization effect, 4) these data supported the idea that elevated CO2 accelerates the spatial turnover of soil microbial communities, 5) we found that although warming increases soil respiration rates, there is limited evidence for a shifting respiration response with experimental warming, suggesting similar temperature acclimation of soil microbes to both experimental and seasonal temperature change, indicating warming experiments are a strong proxy for climate change, and 6) we made a comprehensive analysis of warming induced changes in soil carbon stocks across multiple warming experiments – we found that the effects of warming were contingent on the size of the initial soil carbon stocks. By extrapolating this empirical relationship to the global scale, we provided estimates of soil carbon sensitivity to warming that may help to constrain Earth system model projections.
